datafield.subfield: 8.3 linear feet in 9 boxes (including outsize), and 1 outsize folder.

Douglas Fergusson Roby was a University of Michigan graduate (Class 1923). He was member of the International Olympic Committee from 1952-1985 and president of the United States Olympic Committee from 1965 to 1969.
He was elected president of the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States in 1951. Roby made several attempts to bring the Olympic games to Detroit from 1944 to the 1972 Olympiads.

The collection includes materials related to Roby's professional activities and interests and contains personal files, national and international Olympic and athletic organizations’ files and photographs, as well as Roby’s personal files and photographs. The collection is divided into three series: Personal/Biographical, The Olympic Games, and Photographs and Photo Albums.

The Personal/Biographical series contains material concerning Roby’s early life and business activities, as well as speeches, writings, and a scrapbook. Found here is material related to his years at the University of Michigan and Phillips University in Enid, Oklahoma. Also included here is material related to Roby's business activities, his involvement with Detroit civic organizations, newspaper articles related to him, and a scrapbook.

The Olympic Games series is the largest series in the collection and encompasses Roby’s activities in various national and international sports associations, including the Amateur Athletic Association, the U.S. Olympic Committee, and the International Olympic Committee. This series also includes material related to individual Olympic Games and Pan American Games, Olympic bids --specifically, Detroit and Los Angeles--and various issues that arose in preparation to and during Olympiads.
